column20:
The Annual Report has been prepared in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act.
In our opinion the financial statements give a true and fair view of Belcom Inc. Aps`s financial position at 31. December 2013 and of the result of the companyâs operations and cash flows for the
financial year 1. January â 31. December 2013.
column23:
Unusual circumstances.
Because of the Dutch taxation authorities, the company was incurring additional costs in the form of
transferpricing for approx. EUR 20.592
This will continue to affect results negatively by approx. EUR 22.800 per year.

Uncertainty regarding recognition and measurement.
There has been no uncertainty regarding the recognition and measurement.
column25:
Evolution of operation and financial position.
The operation shows a small surplus which, however, are turned into deficit due Dutch tax authoritiesÂ´ requirements on transfer pricing payments from Belcom to the company in the Netherlands.
New customers have agreed to marketing BelcomÂ´s products starting in mid-2014. This is expected to result in a significant improvement in the result for 2014.
column26:
Recognition and measurement in general
Earnings are listed in the profit and loss account as they are generated. Included are also value adjustments of financial assets and liabilities. All costs, including depreciation, amortisation and write-down, are also listed in the profit and loss account.
Assets are listed in the balance sheet when it is likely that future financial benefits will flow to the company and when a reliable assessment of the asset value can be made.
Liabilities are listed in the balance sheet when it is likely that future financial benefits will flow out
of the company and when a reliable assessment of the liability value can be made.
The first recognition includes a value assessment of assets and liabilities at cost price. The
value of the assets and liabilities is subsequently assessed as described for each individual item below.
When recognising and measuring one must allow for the predictable losses and risks that might occur before the annual report is submitted and that might confirm or invalidate circumstances prevailing on the balance sheet date.
column27:
Administrative costs
Recognised in the administrative costs are costs incurred during the year in connection with
management and administration of the company, including costs relating to the administration,
management and offices along with office expenditure etc.
column28:
Production costs
Production costs are costs incurred in order to reach this year's net turnover figure.
column29:
Prepayments and accrued income
Prepayments and accrued income listed under assets include expenses paid for the following
financial year.
column30:
Financial items
Financial income and expenses include interest earnings and expenses. Financial income and
expenses are listed with the amounts relating to the financial year in question.
column31:
Goodwill
Goodwill is amortised over the expected useful life which is determined on the basis of
management experience within the individual business areas. Goodwill is subject to straight-line
amortisation for a maximum of 10 years.
column32:
Inventories
Inventories are listed at cost price based on the weighted average prices. In the event that the
cost price is higher than the net realisable value, the figure is reduced to that lower value.
column33:
Financial liabilities
Other debt or liabilities covering trade creditors, associated and affiliated companies undertakings and other debt are listed at amortised cost price, which is usually the equivalent of the nominal value.
column34:
Accounts receivable
Accounts receivable are listed at amortised cost price, which usually corresponds to the nominal
value. Write-down is made at the net realisable value to provide for expected losses.
column35:
Net turnover
Net turnover generated in connection with the sale of goods for resale and manufactured goods are listed in the profit and loss account if delivery and risk assignment to purchaser has taken place before the end of the year and if a reliable estimate of earnings can be made and a receipt of these earnings be expected. Net turnover are listed exclusive of VAT, taxes and less any sales discount.
column36:
Corporation tax and deferred tax
Tax for the year includes current tax and changes in deferred tax and is listed in the profit and
loss account with the ratio referring to the net profit/loss for the year and recognised in equity
with the ratio referring to entries with direct reference to the equity.
Deferred tax is assessed according to the balance-oriented liability method in respect of all
temporary differences between book value and tax value of the assets and liabilities.
column37:
Conversion of foreign currency
Transactions in foreign currency are converted according to the exchange rate in force as at the transaction date. Currency differences occurring between the prevailing rate as at the
transaction date and that as at the payment date are listed in the profit and loss account as a
financial item.
Accounts receivable, debt and other monetary items in foreign currency that have not been
settled as at the balance sheet date will be converted into the exchange rate in force as at the
balance sheet date. The difference between the rate in force as at the balance sheet date and
that applying when the outstanding account or debt was established is listed in the profit and
loss account under financial income and expenses.
column38:
Main activities.
The companyâs main activity is trade.
column39:
Events after the reporting period.
After closing the period there has been no events, which could materially
affect the companyÂ´s financial position of 31. December 2013.

column78:
Basis of review
We conducted our review in accordance with the international Standard on Review of financial statements and additional requirements under Danish Audit Regulation. This standard requires that we plan and perform the review to obtain limited assurance about whether the financial statements are free from material misstatement. A review is first and foremost limited to include inquiries to the management and the employees of the company and to analyses of accounting figures and, therefore, provides less assurance than an audit. We have not performed an audit and, accordingly, we do not express an audit opinion on the financial statements.

Prepayments and accrued income listed under assets include expenses paid for the following
financial year.
column30:
Financial items
Financial income and expenses include interest earnings and expenses. Financial income and
expenses are listed with the amounts relating to the financial year in question.
column31:
Goodwill
Goodwill is amortised over the expected useful life which is determined on the basis of
management experience within the individual business areas. Goodwill is subject to straight-line
amortisation for a maximum of 10 years.
column32:
Inventories
Inventories are listed at cost price based on the weighted average prices. In the event that the
cost price is higher than the net realisable value, the figure is reduced to that lower value.
column33:
Financial liabilities
Other debt or liabilities covering trade creditors, associated and affiliated companies undertakings and other debt are listed at amortised cost price, which is usually the equivalent of the nominal value.
column34:
Accounts receivable
Accounts receivable are listed at amortised cost price, which usually corresponds to the nominal
value. Write-down is made at the net realisable value to provide for expected losses.
column35:
Net turnover
Net turnover generated in connection with the sale of goods for resale and manufactured goods are listed in the profit and loss account if delivery and risk assignment to purchaser has taken place before the end of the year and if a reliable estimate of earnings can be made and a receipt of these earnings be expected. Net turnover are listed exclusive of VAT, taxes and less any sales discount.
column36:
Corporation tax and deferred tax
Tax for the year includes current tax and changes in deferred tax and is listed in the profit and
loss account with the ratio referring to the net profit/loss for the year and recognised in equity
with the ratio referring to entries with direct reference to the equity.
Deferred tax is assessed according to the balance-oriented liability method in respect of all
temporary differences between book value and tax value of the assets and liabilities.
column37:
Conversion of foreign currency
Transactions in foreign currency are converted according to the exchange rate in force as at the transaction date. Currency differences occurring between the prevailing rate as at the
transaction date and that as at the payment date are listed in the profit and loss account as a
financial item.
Accounts receivable, debt and other monetary items in foreign currency that have not been
settled as at the balance sheet date will be converted into the exchange rate in force as at the
balance sheet date. The difference between the rate in force as at the balance sheet date and
that applying when the outstanding account or debt was established is listed in the profit and
loss account under financial income and expenses.
column38:
Main activities.
The companyâs main activity is trade.
column39:
Events after the reporting period.
After closing the period there has been no events, which could materially
affect the companyÂ´s financial position of 31. December 2013.

column77: Leadership endorsement
column78:
Basis of review
We conducted our review in accordance with the international Standard on Review of financial statements and additional requirements under Danish Audit Regulation. This standard requires that we plan and perform the review to obtain limited assurance about whether the financial statements are free from material misstatement. A review is first and foremost limited to include inquiries to the management and the employees of the company and to analyses of accounting figures and, therefore, provides less assurance than an audit. We have not performed an audit and, accordingly, we do not express an audit opinion on the financial statements.

column80:
We have reviewed the financial statements of Belcom Inc. ApS for the financial year 1 January â 31 December 2013. The financial statements which comprise summary of significant accounting policies, income statement, balance sheet and notes are prepared in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act.
The management of the company is responsible for the financial statements. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the financial statements based on our review.

column20:
The Annual Report has been prepared in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act.
In our opinion the financial statements give a true and fair view of Belcom Inc. Aps`s financial position at 31. December 2013 and of the result of the companyâs operations and cash flows for the
financial year 1. January â 31. December 2013.
column23:
Unusual circumstances.
Because of the Dutch taxation authorities, the company was incurring additional costs in the form of
transferpricing for approx. EUR 20.592
This will continue to affect results negatively by approx. EUR 22.800 per year.

Uncertainty regarding recognition and measurement.
There has been no uncertainty regarding the recognition and measurement.
column25:
Evolution of operation and financial position.
The operation shows a small surplus which, however, are turned into deficit due Dutch tax authoritiesÂ´ requirements on transfer pricing payments from Belcom to the company in the Netherlands.
New customers have agreed to marketing BelcomÂ´s products starting in mid-2014. This is expected to result in a significant improvement in the result for 2014.
column26:
Recognition and measurement in general
Earnings are listed in the profit and loss account as they are generated. Included are also value adjustments of financial assets and liabilities. All costs, including depreciation, amortisation and write-down, are also listed in the profit and loss account.
Assets are listed in the balance sheet when it is likely that future financial benefits will flow to the company and when a reliable assessment of the asset value can be made.
Liabilities are listed in the balance sheet when it is likely that future financial benefits will flow out
of the company and when a reliable assessment of the liability value can be made.
The first recognition includes a value assessment of assets and liabilities at cost price. The
value of the assets and liabilities is subsequently assessed as described for each individual item below.
When recognising and measuring one must allow for the predictable losses and risks that might occur before the annual report is submitted and that might confirm or invalidate circumstances prevailing on the balance sheet date.
column27:
Administrative costs
Recognised in the administrative costs are costs incurred during the year in connection with
management and administration of the company, including costs relating to the administration,
management and offices along with office expenditure etc.
column28:
Production costs
Production costs are costs incurred in order to reach this year's net turnover figure.
column29:
Prepayments and accrued income
Prepayments and accrued income listed under assets include expenses paid for the following
financial year.
column30:
Financial items
Financial income and expenses include interest earnings and expenses. Financial income and
expenses are listed with the amounts relating to the financial year in question.
column31:

Net turnover are listed exclusive of VAT, taxes and less any sales discount.

Accounts receivable, debt and other monetary items in foreign currency that have not been
settled as at the balance sheet date will be converted into the exchange rate in force as at the
balance sheet date. The difference between the rate in force as at the balance sheet date and
that applying when the outstanding account or debt was established is listed in the profit and
loss account under financial income and expenses.

column78:
Basis of review
We conducted our review in accordance with the international Standard on Review of financial statements and additional requirements under Danish Audit Regulation. This standard requires that we plan and perform the review to obtain limited assurance about whether the financial statements are free from material misstatement. A review is first and foremost limited to include inquiries to the management and the employees of the company and to analyses of accounting figures and, therefore, provides less assurance than an audit. We have not performed an audit and, accordingly, we do not express an audit opinion on the financial statements.

column20:
The Annual Report has been prepared in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act.
In our opinion the financial statements give a true and fair view of Belcom Inc. Aps`s financial position at 31. December 2013 and of the result of the companyâs operations and cash flows for the

column23:
Unusual circumstances.
Because of the Dutch taxation authorities, the company was incurring additional costs in the form of
transferpricing for approx. EUR 20.592
This will continue to affect results negatively by approx. EUR 22.800 per year.

Uncertainty regarding recognition and measurement.
There has been no uncertainty regarding the recognition and measurement.
column25:
Evolution of operation and financial position.
The operation shows a small surplus which, however, are turned into deficit due Dutch tax authoritiesÂ´ requirements on transfer pricing payments from Belcom to the company in the Netherlands.
New customers have agreed to marketing BelcomÂ´s products starting in mid-2014. This is expected to result in a significant improvement in the result for 2014.
column26:
Recognition and measurement in general
Earnings are listed in the profit and loss account as they are generated. Included are also value adjustments of financial assets and liabilities. All costs, including depreciation, amortisation and write-down, are also listed in the profit and loss account.
Assets are listed in the balance sheet when it is likely that future financial benefits will flow to the company and when a reliable assessment of the asset value can be made.
Liabilities are listed in the balance sheet when it is likely that future financial benefits will flow out
of the company and when a reliable assessment of the liability value can be made.
The first recognition includes a value assessment of assets and liabilities at cost price. The
value of the assets and liabilities is subsequently assessed as described for each individual item below.
When recognising and measuring one must allow for the predictable losses and risks that might occur before the annual report is submitted and that might confirm or invalidate circumstances prevailing on the balance sheet date.
column27:
Administrative costs
Recognised in the administrative costs are costs incurred during the year in connection with
management and administration of the company, including costs relating to the administration,
management and offices along with office expenditure etc.
column28:
Production costs
Production costs are costs incurred in order to reach this year's net turnover figure.
column29:
Prepayments and accrued income
Prepayments and accrued income listed under assets include expenses paid for the following
financial year.
column30:
Financial items
Financial income and expenses include interest earnings and expenses. Financial income and
expenses are listed with the amounts relating to the financial year in question.
column31:
Goodwill
Goodwill is amortised over the expected useful life which is determined on the basis of
management experience within the individual business areas. Goodwill is subject to straight-line
amortisation for a maximum of 10 years.
column32:
Inventories
Inventories are listed at cost price based on the weighted average prices. In the event that the
cost price is higher than the net realisable value, the figure is reduced to that lower value.
column33:
Financial liabilities
Other debt or liabilities covering trade creditors, associated and affiliated companies undertakings and other debt are listed at amortised cost price, which is usually the equivalent of the nominal value.
column34:
Accounts receivable
Accounts receivable are listed at amortised cost price, which usually corresponds to the nominal
value. Write-down is made at the net realisable value to provide for expected losses.
column35:
Net turnover
Net turnover generated in connection with the sale of goods for resale and manufactured goods are listed in the profit and loss account if delivery and risk assignment to purchaser has taken place before the end of the year and if a reliable estimate of earnings can be made and a receipt of these earnings be expected. Net turnover are listed exclusive of VAT, taxes and less any sales discount.
column36:
Corporation tax and deferred tax
Tax for the year includes current tax and changes in deferred tax and is listed in the profit and
loss account with the ratio referring to the net profit/loss for the year and recognised in equity
with the ratio referring to entries with direct reference to the equity.
Deferred tax is assessed according to the balance-oriented liability method in respect of all
temporary differences between book value and tax value of the assets and liabilities.
column37:
Conversion of foreign currency
Transactions in foreign currency are converted according to the exchange rate in force as at the transaction date. Currency differences occurring between the prevailing rate as at the
transaction date and that as at the payment date are listed in the profit and loss account as a
financial item.
Accounts receivable, debt and other monetary items in foreign currency that have not been
settled as at the balance sheet date will be converted into the exchange rate in force as at the
balance sheet date. The difference between the rate in force as at the balance sheet date and
that applying when the outstanding account or debt was established is listed in the profit and
loss account under financial income and expenses.
